content.description: “[The economic and social] revolution which broke out between 1789 and 1848 . . . has transformed, and continues to transform, the entire world. . . . [However,] the revolution of 1789–1848 was the triumph not of industry, but of capitalist industry; not of liberty and equality in general, but of the middle class or bourgeois liberal society; not of the modern economy or the modern state, but of the economies and states in a particular geographical region . . . whose center was the neighboring and rival states of Great Britain and France.”
content.question:
In your response, be sure to address all parts of the question. Use complete sentences; an outline or bulleted list alone is not acceptable.

a) Describe in your own words one of the author’s claims regarding the revolutionary transformation of Europe between 1789 and 1848.

b) Identify one piece of evidence not found in the passage that would support the author’s argument regarding a social effect of industrialization.

c) Explain how the author's Marxist point of view shapes his interpretation of industrial capitalism.
